oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: John Caldwell Calhoun
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Portrait engraving of South Carolinian John C. Calhoun based on Matthew Brady's daguerreotype completed around 1849. Calhoun's stern visage is an iconic image of the old states rights warrior, proto-secessionist, and nemesis of his Unionist fellow Southerner, Andrew Jackson.

As the chief spokesman for the increasingly aggressive rights of the slaveholding South, John C. Calhoun was one of the giants of antebellum American politics. He served as War Hawk congressman, Secretary of War (1817-1825), Vice President (1825-1832) and US Senator (1835-1850).
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Hall, Henry Bryan, active 1850-1900
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Calhoun, John Caldwell, 1782-1850; Brady, Mathew B., approximately 1823-1896
Engravings; Portraits
